# Task

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.



# Data

df = DataFrame(dt=[DateTime(2020, 5, 24), DateTime(2021, 1, 15), DateTime(2022, 12, 5)])
add_yearmonth(df)

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = [Dates.year(x)*100 + Dates.month(x) for x in df.dt]
end
```
The above function `add_yearmonth` takes a DataFrame as input and adds a new column `:ym` to it. For each row in the input DataFrame, this function extracts the year and month from the DateTime value in the `:dt` column, concatenates them together into an integer format "yyyymm", and stores this value in the newly created `:ym` column.

Note: This solution assumes that your DataFrame has a column named `dt` representing DateTimes and you're using the Julia package `DataFrames`. The DateTime format is assumed to be in the year-month-day order (year first, then month).

Now let's apply this function on our given dataframe.
```julia
df = DataFrame(dt=[DateTime(2020, 5, 24), DateTime(2021, 1, 15), DateTime(2022, 12, 5)])
add_yearmonth(df)
```
This will add a new column `:ym` to the DataFrame `df`, with values [20205, 20211, 202212].
